bibl.title: Letter from Walter Reed to Dorsey M. McPherson, February 27, 1880

div1.p: Reed writes of a post controversy regarding officers' duties and conduct.

div1.head: Letter from Walter Reed to Dorsey M. McPherson, February 27, 1880
div1.p:
Your last favor to hand-
Orders No. 1. will be filed away, to be called
into use, should Mr Lyons ever come
back to Apache- As he has never signed
the Muster Rolls, of course he can't be
paid- However, Uncle Sam will be kind
to him, I know, and one of these days, when
he duly affixes his “fist” to the Rolls, I will see
that he is rewarded with his Sheckels-
It isn't often my dear boy that we have
any news here, but Apache is to the
front this time sure- Johannes Viven,
otherwise & more familiarly known as
“Jack”, has actually preferred charges
against the K.O.!

Hesche! How?
Take a full breath, my boy, and steady
yourself & I'll explain- It came to pass
after this wise- About a week ago,
a prisoner escaped from the sentinel-
His name is Andy Rouske, the same
gent who threatened to “put a head” on
on the good “Manny” Gatewood-
It furthermore so happened that Jack
was Officer of the day, & was just sitting
down to his oat-meal when the Serg't.
of the Guard reported Rouske's escape-
Jack continued his breakfast & did not
notify the K.O. of itthe prisoner's escape till he reported
at the office after G. Mommt- The K.O.
at once put two Indians on the prisoner's
track & found him lying down in the Cañon
back of our quarters, about 300 yards
from the place whence the festive Andy
took his flight- The K.O. thereupon requested
Jack to state in writing why he did not
take more energetic means for the capture
of the prisoners, and upon the Jacks sending in
his explanation, the K.O. sat down & wrote
him a sharp communication, telling him
that his explanation was “unsatisfactory”,
and that in his opinion Jack was “guilty
of gross neglect of duty” and that in
the future, a more cheerful & energetic
discharge of duty would be expected
of Cap't. Viven”- Hesche! Thereupon
Jack sits down & askeds for a Court
of Inquiry, to investigate the facts,
& in his application stated that he
thought, if he was granted a Court,
“that facts would be developed con-
-cerning the discharge of duty by Officers
at this Post, which should come to the
notice of the Dep't. Commander”! Hesche!
When the eyes of the K.O. fell upon
these words, he was wroth within him-
self, & he sent that application back to
Jack “awhizzing”! directing Johannes
“to state in explicit terms” any facts
he had concerning the discharge of
duty by officers at this Post- In a 2nd
Endorsement, John respectfully de-
-clined, saying that these “facts” were
a part of his defence & intended for
the perceptive ear of the Dep't. Commander
only. The K.O. refused to “see it” in that
light, and in a 3rd End.mt tells Jack that
he will send in charges (formal
charges, Dorsey,) against the before-
mentioned “Officers”, and that he will
do it p. d. q -- ! & if he didn't comply,
“his refusual would be construed
into intentional disobedience of
orders”! wasn't that brave in the
dear man? Result -- 5 charges and
15 specifications, & they are now
at Camp Thomas, on their way
to the Head fountain- The charges
& specifications include drunkenness on duty,
gambling, neglecting repair of barracks
building an elaborate (that's the
very word used, my dear boy,) cons-
stable, (Hesche!) lending government
property, neglecting his duty, & any-
& everything else you can think
off- Only 25 witnesses! How?
Well, “I want to know”! Now Camp
Thomas may think, Dorsey, that it is
quite a fine place, but it must
yield the palm to Apache, this time,
for having “gone one better”! I re-
frain from expressing any opinion-
Adrian waits at the door for this
letter- I have written in the great-
est haste, but if I haven't given
you food for reflection for 15
minutes, why, then I'm a liar-
div1.closer:
Love to all - ever
your friend, Billy Reed, Duke of the Gila-
